title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Maximum 5 background tasks running simultaneously launching multiple agents (e.g., mass audits), batch groups 5 Wait current batch complete launching next batch

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: NEVER use Urban Institute API, NCES CCD, federal data source — entire point packages provide STATE-LEVEL data directly state . Federal sources aggregate/transform data differently lose state-specific details. state DOE source broken, FIX find alternative STATE source — fall back federal data.

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Commits allowed Claude Code attribution, Co-Authored-trailers, emojis Write normal commit messages human wrote

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: PRs merged CI passes. Run checks locally opening PR:

title: Claude Code Instructions
code: # R package check (required) devtools::check()  # Python tests (required) system("pip install -e ./pymaschooldata && pytest tests/test_pymaschooldata.py -v")  # pkgdown build (required) pkgdown::build_site()

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: opening PR, verify: - [ ] devtools::check() — 0 errors, 0 warnings - [ ] pytest tests/test_pymaschooldata.py — tests pass - [ ] pkgdown::build_site() — builds without errors - [ ] Vignettes render (eval=FALSE hacks)

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: package includes tests/testthat/test-pipeline-live.R LIVE network tests.

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: URL Availability - HTTP 200 checks File Download - Verify actual file (HTML error) File Parsing - readxl/readr succeeds Column Structure - Expected columns exist get_raw_enr() - Raw data function works Data Quality - Inf/NaN, non-negative counts Aggregation - State total > 0 Output Fidelity - tidy=TRUE matches raw

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: See state-schooldata/CLAUDE.md complete testing framework documentation.
code: devtools::test(filter = "pipeline-live")

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: NEVER push directly main. changes must go PRs auto-merge:
code: # 1. Create feature branch git checkout -b fix/description-of-change  # 2. Make changes, commit git add -A git commit -m "Fix: description of change"  # 3. Push and create PR with auto-merge git push -u origin fix/description-of-change gh pr create --title "Fix: description" --body "Description of changes" gh pr merge --auto --squash  # 4. Clean up stale branches after PR merges git checkout main && git pull && git fetch --prune origin

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: Clean stale branches every time touch package:
code: # Delete local branches merged to main git branch --merged main | grep -v main | xargs -r git branch -d  # Prune remote tracking branches git fetch --prune origin

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: PRs auto-merge CI checks pass: - R-CMD-check (0 errors, 0 warnings) - Python tests (py{st}schooldata exists) - pkgdown build (vignettes must render) CI fails, fix issue push - auto-merge trigger checks pass.

title: Claude Code Instructions
text: NEVER use man/figures/ generate_readme_figs.R README images. README images MUST come pkgdown-generated vignette output auto-update merge: Example maschooldata: : Vignette figures regenerate automatically pkgdown builds. Manual man/figures/ requires running separate script easy forget, causing stale/broken images.
code: ![Chart name](https://almartin82.github.io/{package}/articles/{vignette}_files/figure-html/{chunk-name}-1.png) ![Charter enrollment](https://almartin82.github.io/maschooldata/articles/enrollment-trends_files/figure-html/charter-enrollment-1.png)

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research

what: Source 1: High School Graduation Rates (Primary - Recommended)
title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Dataset ID: n2xa-p822 URL: https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/Assessment--Accountability/High-School-Graduation-Rates/n2xa-p822 API Endpoint: https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/resource/n2xa-p822.json HTTP Status: 200 OK (verified) Format: Socrata API (JSON/CSV) Years Available: 2006-2024 (19 years) Access: Direct API access, authentication required Last Modified: 2025-05-02 Record Count: ~411,000 total records

what: Source 2: State and District High School Graduation Rates (DART)
title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Dataset ID: u57w-6nby URL: https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/Assessment--Accountability/State--District-High-School-Graduation-Rates/u57w-6nby API Endpoint: https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/resource/u57w-6nby.json HTTP Status: 200 OK (verified) Format: Socrata API (JSON/CSV) Years Available: 2024 (likely multi-year, needs verification) Access: Direct API access, authentication required Last Modified: 2025-10-28 Note: DART (District Analysis Review Tool) dataset different structure

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Schema consistent across available years (2006-2024) Percentages stored decimals (0.884 = 88.4%) column name changes detected

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: State ID: 00000000 District ID: 8 digits, first 4 unique district identifier (e.g., 00350000 Boston district code 0035) School ID: 8 digits, first 4 district, last 4 school within district (e.g., 00350560 = Boston Latin School) Consistent enrollment API ID format

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Suppression: Data reported cohorts fewer 6 students alternative/special schools may low graduation rates (expected recovery schools) exclud_pct (permanently excluded) appears older years typically 0

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: percentages sum approximately 1.0 (100%) grad_pct + in_sch_pct + non_grad_pct + ged_pct + drpout_pct + exclud_pct ≈ 1.0 negative values Cohort count >= 6 reported rows

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Graduation data widely requested education research API stable, well-documented, consistent existing enrollment API

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Socrata API pattern enrollment Schema clean consistent Multiple rate types subgroups add complexity tidy transformation

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: R/get_raw_graduation.R - New file API download R/fetch_graduation.R - New file fetch_grad() function R/tidy_graduation.R - New file tidy transformation tests/testthat/test-graduation-live.R - Live pipeline tests Update R/maschooldata-package.R new functions Update NAMESPACE DESCRIPTION

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Similar get_raw_enr_api() pattern API endpoint: https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/resource/n2xa-p822.json Filter year ?sy=YYYY Handle pagination (set high limit) Standardize column names Convert percentages needed Map org_type consistent levels Pivot graduation rate types columns (4yr, 4yr_adj, 5yr, 5yr_adj) Keep subgroups rows Add aggregation level flags Main user-facing function Parameters: end_year, rate_type, tidy, use_cache Support filtering rate type separate fetch_dropout() combined Dataset cmm7-ttbg similar structure

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
code: # Year 2024 verification test_that("2024 state graduation rate matches API", {   # Expected from API: 88.4% (0.884), cohort 73,046   data <- fetch_grad(2024)   state_4yr <- data |>     filter(org_type == "State", stu_grp == "All Students",            grad_rate_type == "4-Year Graduation Rate")   expect_equal(state_4yr$grad_pct, 0.884)   expect_equal(state_4yr$cohort_cnt, 73046) })  # Year 2007 verification (earliest year) test_that("2007 state graduation rate matches API", {   # Expected: 80.9% (0.809), cohort 75,912   data <- fetch_grad(2007)   state_4yr <- data |>     filter(org_type == "State", stu_grp == "All Students",            grad_rate_type == "4-Year Graduation Rate")   expect_equal(state_4yr$grad_pct, 0.809)   expect_equal(state_4yr$cohort_cnt, 75912) })  # Boston district verification test_that("2024 Boston graduation rate matches API", {   # Expected: 79.7% (0.797), cohort 3,711   data <- fetch_grad(2024)   boston <- data |>     filter(dist_code == "00350000", org_type == "District",            stu_grp == "All Students", grad_rate_type == "4-Year Graduation Rate")   expect_equal(boston$grad_pct, 0.797)   expect_equal(boston$cohort_cnt, 3711) })

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
code: test_that("graduation percentages sum to approximately 1", {   data <- fetch_grad(2024, tidy = FALSE)   data <- data |>     mutate(pct_sum = grad_pct + in_sch_pct + non_grad_pct +                      ged_pct + drpout_pct + exclud_pct)   expect_true(all(data$pct_sum > 0.98 & data$pct_sum < 1.02, na.rm = TRUE)) })  test_that("no negative percentages", {   data <- fetch_grad(2024, tidy = FALSE)   expect_true(all(data$grad_pct >= 0, na.rm = TRUE))   expect_true(all(data$drpout_pct >= 0, na.rm = TRUE)) })  test_that("cohort counts are positive", {   data <- fetch_grad(2024, tidy = FALSE)   expect_true(all(data$cohort_cnt > 0, na.rm = TRUE)) })

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
code: test_that("graduation API returns HTTP 200", {   skip_if_offline()   response <- httr::HEAD(     "https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/resource/n2xa-p822.json",     httr::timeout(30)   )   expect_equal(httr::status_code(response), 200) })  test_that("graduation API returns valid JSON", {   skip_if_offline()   response <- httr::GET(     "https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/resource/n2xa-p822.json?$limit=5",     httr::timeout(30)   )   content <- httr::content(response, as = "text")   data <- jsonlite::fromJSON(content)   expect_true(is.data.frame(data))   expect_gt(nrow(data), 0) })

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Graduation data uses ID system enrollment District codes first 4 digits 8-digit code Can join graduation enrollment using dist_code org_code

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: datasets share subgroups: - Race/ethnicity categories (7 groups) - Gender (Male/Female) - English Learners - Students Disabilities - Low Income / Economically Disadvantaged - High Needs Graduation-subgroups: - Foster Care - Homeless

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Socrata default limit 1000 rows Use $limit=50000 get data year Expected ~20,000-25,000 rows per year (schools, subgroups, rate types)

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: caching approach enrollment Cache year tidy/wide format Approximately 2-3 MB per year uncompressed

title: Massachusetts School Data Expansion Research
text: Option : Include 4 rate types output (4yr, 4yr_adj, 5yr, 5yr_adj) Option B: Default 4-year, parameter select type Recommendation: Option tidy=FALSE, pivot tidy=TRUE Option : Separate fetch_dropout() function Option B: Include dropout part graduation output Recommendation: Option , keep functions focused Option : Always return subgroups Option B: Add subgroup parameter filter Recommendation: Option , let users filter dplyr

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Boston seen steady enrollment decline past decade, losing 10,000 students.
code: boston <- enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id == "0035",          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(boston, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "Boston Public Schools Enrollment",        subtitle = "Steady decline over the past decade",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Springfield, Worcester, Lowell - Massachusetts’ “Gateway Cities” - maintained relatively stable enrollment.
code: gateway <- enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% c("0281", "0365", "0145"),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(gateway, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Gateway Cities Enrollment",        subtitle = "Springfield, Worcester, and Lowell",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: state seen significant shift racial/ethnic composition past decade.
code: demo <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "black", "hispanic", "asian"))  ggplot(demo, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_color_manual(values = colors,                      labels = c("Asian", "Black", "Hispanic", "White")) +   labs(title = "Massachusetts Demographics Shift",        subtitle = "Percent of student population by race/ethnicity",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent", color = "") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Cape Cod Islands seen declining enrollment seasonal communities age.
code: cape <- enr %>%   filter(is_district, grepl("Barnstable|Nauset|Monomoy|Martha|Nantucket", district_name),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(n_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(cape, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Cape and Islands Enrollment",        subtitle = "Combined enrollment for Cape Cod and Island districts",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: pandemic caused sharp drop kindergarten enrollment 2020-21 persisted.
code: k_trend <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "06", "12")) %>%   mutate(grade_label = case_when(     grade_level == "K" ~ "Kindergarten",     grade_level == "01" ~ "Grade 1",     grade_level == "06" ~ "Grade 6",     grade_level == "12" ~ "Grade 12"   ))  ggplot(k_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = grade_label)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   geom_vline(xintercept = 2021, linetype = "dashed", color = "red", alpha = 0.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "COVID Impact on Grade-Level Enrollment",        subtitle = "Kindergarten hit hardest in 2020-21",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Massachusetts charter schools continue expand, serving 40,000 students.
code: charter <- enr %>%   filter(is_charter, is_campus, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(n_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(charter, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Massachusetts Charter School Enrollment",        subtitle = "Total students across all charter schools",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: percentage students classified economically disadvantaged fluctuated years.
code: econ <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "econ_disadv", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(econ, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   labs(title = "Economically Disadvantaged Students",        subtitle = "Percent of MA students classified as economically disadvantaged",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: English Learners concentrated urban districts, Boston leading state.
code: el <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "lep", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(10) %>%   mutate(district_label = reorder(district_name, n_students))  ggplot(el, aes(x = district_label, y = n_students)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "English Learners by District",        subtitle = "Top 10 districts by number of EL students",        x = "", y = "English Learner Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Districts like Newton, Lexington, Wellesley maintained relatively stable enrollment.
code: suburbs <- enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% c("0195", "0139", "0325"),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(suburbs, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Suburban Ring Enrollment",        subtitle = "Newton, Lexington, and Wellesley",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Regional school districts consolidate resources across rural communities.
code: regional <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, grepl("Regional", district_name),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(10) %>%   mutate(district_label = reorder(district_name, n_students))  ggplot(regional, aes(x = district_label, y = n_students)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Regional School Districts",        subtitle = "Top 10 regional districts by enrollment",        x = "", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Springfield, state’s third-largest district, experienced dramatic demographic shift past decade, Hispanic students now comprising majority.
code: springfield_demo <- enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id == "0281", grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "black", "hispanic", "asian"))  ggplot(springfield_demo, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_color_manual(values = colors,                      labels = c("Asian", "Black", "Hispanic", "White")) +   labs(title = "Springfield Demographics Transformation",        subtitle = "Hispanic students now majority in state's third-largest district",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent", color = "") +   theme_readme()

what: 12. Fall River and New Bedford: SouthCoast struggles
title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: two largest SouthCoast cities share similar trajectories - former mill towns persistent economic challenges declining enrollment.
code: southcoast <- enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% c("0079", "0192"),  # Fall River, New Bedford          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(southcoast, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "SouthCoast Enrollment Trends",        subtitle = "Fall River and New Bedford enrollment over time",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Worcester held steady, suburban ring - Shrewsbury, Westborough, Grafton - shows consistent growth.
code: worcester_suburbs <- enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% c("0270", "0330", "0097"),  # Shrewsbury, Westborough, Grafton          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(worcester_suburbs, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Worcester Suburban Growth",        subtitle = "Shrewsbury, Westborough, and Grafton",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Pioneer Valley Berkshire counties seen persistent enrollment declines young families move east state.
code: # Major Western MA districts western_ma <- enr %>%   filter(is_district,          district_id %in% c("0199", "0003", "0211", "0098"),  # Northampton, Amherst, Pittsfield, Great Barrington          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(n_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(western_ma, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Western Massachusetts Enrollment",        subtitle = "Combined enrollment for Northampton, Amherst, Pittsfield, and Great Barrington",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts Enrollment Trends
text: Across Massachusetts, boys identified special education services nearly twice rate girls.
code: sped_gender <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("sped", "male", "female")) %>%   select(subgroup, n_students, pct)  # Get gender breakdown within SPED at district level sped_by_district <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "sped", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(15) %>%   mutate(district_label = reorder(district_name, pct))  ggplot(sped_by_district, aes(x = district_label, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   labs(title = "Special Education Rates by District",        subtitle = "Top 15 districts by percent of students receiving SPED services",        x = "", y = "Percent SPED") +   theme_readme()

title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Documentation | Getting Started Fetch analyze Massachusetts school enrollment data Department Elementary Secondary Education (DESE) R Python.

what: What can you find with maschooldata?
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: 30+ years enrollment data (1994-2025). 920,000 students today. 400 districts. fifteen stories hiding numbers:

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Boston Public Schools lost 20,000 students since peak. Today enrolls around 48,000.
code: library(maschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, 2020, 2025))  enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id == "0035",          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Springfield, Worcester, Lowell struggling enrollment demographics shift dramatically.
code: gateway <- c("0281", "0365", "0145")  # Springfield, Worcester, Lowell  enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% gateway,          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: state gone 80% white 60% white 25 years. Hispanic students now exceed 20%.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2000, 2010, 2020, 2025))  enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "black", "hispanic", "asian")) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   select(end_year, subgroup, n_students, pct)

what: 9. The suburban ring is holding steady
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Newton, Lexington, Wellesley maintain enrollment urban cores decline.
code: suburbs <- c("0195", "0139", "0325")  # Newton, Lexington, Wellesley  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% suburbs,          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
what: 10. Regional school districts dominate rural Massachusetts
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: 50 regional districts serve students multiple towns, uniquely Massachusetts approach.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, grepl("Regional", district_name),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   select(district_name, n_students) %>%   head(10)

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Springfield, state’s third-largest district, seen Hispanic students become majority past decade.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2016:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id == "0281", grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "black", "hispanic", "asian")) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   select(end_year, subgroup, pct)

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
what: 12. Fall River and New Bedford: SouthCoast struggles
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Two former mill cities similar trajectories - persistent economic challenges declining enrollment.
code: southcoast <- c("0079", "0192")  # Fall River, New Bedford  enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% southcoast,          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Worcester holds steady, suburban ring - Shrewsbury, Westborough, Grafton - shows consistent growth.
code: worcester_ring <- c("0270", "0330", "0097")  # Shrewsbury, Westborough, Grafton  enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% worcester_ring,          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Pioneer Valley Berkshire counties seen persistent enrollment declines young families move east state.
code: western <- c("0199", "0003", "0211", "0098")  # Northampton, Amherst, Pittsfield, Great Barrington  enr %>%   filter(is_district, district_id %in% western,          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE))

previous_headings: What can you find with maschooldata?
what: 15. Special education rates vary widely by district
title: Massachusetts School Data
text: districts identify nearly 25% students special education services, others 15%.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "sped", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   select(district_name, n_students, pct) %>%   head(15)

title: Massachusetts School Data
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("almartin82/maschooldata")

title: Massachusetts School Data
code: library(maschooldata) library(dplyr)  # Fetch one year enr_2025 <- fetch_enr(2025)  # Fetch multiple years enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2020:2025)  # State totals enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  # District breakdown enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students))  # Boston demographics enr_2025 %>%   filter(district_id == "0035", grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "black", "hispanic", "asian")) %>%   select(subgroup, n_students, pct)

title: Massachusetts School Data
code: import pymaschooldata as ma  # Fetch 2025 data (2024-25 school year) enr = ma.fetch_enr(2025)  # Statewide total total = enr[(enr['is_state']) & (enr['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL') &             (enr['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment')]['n_students'].sum() print(f"{total:,} students") #> 920,000 students  # Get multiple years enr_multi = ma.fetch_enr_multi([2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025])  # Check available years years = ma.get_available_years() print(f"Data available: {years['min_year']}-{years['max_year']}") #> Data available: 1994-2025

title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Data accessed via Massachusetts Education--Career Research Data Hub: https://educationtocareer.data.mass.gov/d/t8td-gens

title: Massachusetts School Data
text: Levels: State, District (400+), School (1,800+) Demographics: White, Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, Pacific Islander (1998+), Multiracial (2003+) Special populations: Students disabilities, English learners, Low income / Economically disadvantaged Grade levels: PK 12, plus SPED beyond Grade 12

title: Massachusetts School Data
text: District IDs: 4-digit codes (e.g., 0035 = Boston) Economic indicator changes: Pre-2015 used “Low Income”, 2015-2021 used “Economically Disadvantaged”, 2022+ uses “Low Income” Charter schools: Included charter flag filtering Regional districts: Many multi-town districts “Regional” name

title: Fetch Massachusetts enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Downloads processes enrollment data Massachusetts Department Elementary Secondary Education (DESE) via Socrata API (educationtocareer.data.mass.gov).

title: Fetch Massachusetts enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: fetch_enr(end_year, tidy = TRUE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Fetch Massachusetts enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: end_year school year. Year end academic year - eg 2023-24 school year year '2024'. Valid values 1994-2025. tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format subgroup column. FALSE, returns wide format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available. Set FALSE force re-download DESE.

title: Fetch Massachusetts enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Data frame enrollment data. Wide format includes columns district_id, campus_id, names, enrollment counts demographic/grade. Tidy format pivots counts subgroup grade_level columns.

title: Fetch Massachusetts enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 2025 enrollment data (2024-25 school year) enr_2025 <- fetch_enr(2025)  # Get historical data from 2000 enr_2000 <- fetch_enr(2000)  # Get wide format enr_wide <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = FALSE)  # Force fresh download (ignore cache) enr_fresh <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = FALSE)  # Filter to Boston Public Schools boston <- enr_2025 |>   dplyr::filter(district_id == "0035") } # }

what: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
title: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
text: Downloads processes school data Massachusetts Department Elementary Secondary Education (DESE). Provides functions fetching enrollment data SIMS (Student Information Management System) transforming tidy format analysis.

title: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
text: fetch_enr Fetch enrollment data school year fetch_enr_multi Fetch enrollment data multiple years tidy_enr Transform wide data tidy (long) format id_enr_aggs Add aggregation level flags enr_grade_aggs Create grade-level aggregations get_available_years List available data years

title: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
text: cache_status View cached data files clear_cache Remove cached data files

title: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
text: Massachusetts uses hierarchical ID system: District IDs: 4 digits (e.g., 0350 = Boston) School IDs: 8 digits (district ID + 4-digit school number, e.g., 03500010)

title: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
text: Data sourced Massachusetts DESE website: Enrollment Reports: https://www.doe.mass.edu/infoservices/reports/enroll/ SIMS: https://www.doe.mass.edu/InfoServices/data/sims/ School Profiles: https://profiles.doe.mass.edu/

title: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
text: Excel downloads: 2017-2024 (school years 2016-17 2023-24) Profiles system: 2000-2025 (enrollment race/gender reports)

title: maschooldata: Fetch and Process Massachusetts School Data — maschooldata-package
text: Maintainer: Al Martin almartin@example.com
